security_audit.summary: This is a pure documentation and guidance skill for statistical analysis. It contains educational markdown files and one legitimate Python utility script for statistical calculations. No network access, file system access beyond its own directory, environment variable reading, external command execution, or suspicious code patterns detected.

content.value_statement: Statistical analysis skills are essential for research but require proper methodology. This toolkit provides comprehensive guidance on hypothesis testing, regression, Bayesian methods, and APA reporting to help researchers conduct rigorous, reproducible analyses.
actual_capabilities: Conduct hypothesis tests including t-tests, ANOVA, chi-square, and non-parametric alternatives
Perform regression analysis with linear, multiple, and logistic regression models
Calculate effect sizes and conduct power analyses for study planning
Check statistical assumptions with automated diagnostic tools
Apply Bayesian methods including Bayesian t-tests and regression with Bayes Factors
Generate APA-style statistical reports with proper formatting
limitations: Does not process user data files directly; users must provide their own datasets
Does not include data cleaning or preprocessing utilities
Does not perform machine learning or predictive modeling
Users need to install Python packages like scipy, statsmodels, pingouin, and pymc

use_cases.title: Statistical hypothesis testing

prompt_templates.title: Compare two groups
prompt_templates.prompt: Help me compare two groups using a t-test. I have scores for group A and group B. Check assumptions first, run the analysis, calculate Cohen's d, and report in APA format.

prompt_templates.title: Select statistical test
prompt_templates.prompt: I need to analyze the relationship between [variable type] and [variable type]. My data has [n] observations and [describe distribution]. What test should I use and how do I run it?

prompt_templates.title: Run power analysis
prompt_templates.prompt: Help me conduct an a priori power analysis for my study. I expect an effect size of [d], want 80% power, and will use alpha = 0.05. What sample size do I need?

prompt_templates.title: Bayesian analysis
prompt_templates.prompt: Run a Bayesian t-test comparing my two groups. Use weakly informative priors. Report the Bayes Factor, posterior mean difference with 95% credible interval, and probability that one group is higher.

output_examples.input: Compare test scores between treatment and control groups
output: Independent t-test: t(98) = 3.82, p < .001, Cohen's d = 0.77
Assumptions met: normality (both groups) and homogeneity of variance
APA format: Group A (M = 75.2, SD = 8.5) scored significantly higher than Group B (M = 68.3, SD = 9.2), t(98) = 3.82, p < .001, d = 0.77

best_practices: Always check statistical assumptions before interpreting results and report findings
Report effect sizes with confidence intervals, not just p-values
Pre-register your analysis plan to distinguish confirmatory from exploratory findings
anti_patterns: Do not run multiple tests until finding a significant result (p-hacking)
Do not confuse statistical significance with practical importance
Do not omit effect sizes or non-significant findings from your report

faq.question: What sample size do I need for my study?
faq.answer: Conduct an a priori power analysis specifying expected effect size, alpha level (typically 0.05), and desired power (typically 0.80). Use statsmodels or pingouin to calculate required sample size.

faq.question: How do I check if my data meets normality assumptions?
faq.answer: Use Shapiro-Wilk test for small samples (n < 50), visual Q-Q plots for all sample sizes, and examine histograms. For large samples (n > 100), rely primarily on visual inspection.

faq.question: When should I use non-parametric tests instead of t-tests?
faq.answer: Use non-parametric tests (Mann-Whitney, Wilcoxon) when normality is severely violated and sample size is small, or when data is ordinal. Consider transformation if violations are mild.

faq.question: How do I handle multiple comparisons in my analysis?
faq.answer: Apply corrections like Bonferroni for strict control or Tukey's HSD for post-hoc ANOVA comparisons. FDR (Benjamini-Hochberg) offers a less conservative approach for exploratory analyses.

faq.question: What effect size should I report for different tests?
faq.answer: Report Cohen's d for t-tests, eta-squared or partial eta-squared for ANOVA, r for correlations, R-squared for regression, and Cramer's V for chi-square tests. Always include confidence intervals.

faq.question: When should I use Bayesian instead of frequentist methods?
faq.answer: Use Bayesian methods when you have prior information to incorporate, want direct probability statements, have small samples, need evidence for the null hypothesis, or are conducting sequential analyses.
